facts.text: Writ Petition No. 322 of 1974 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 322 of 1974.  Petition Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petitioner Ram Bali Rajbhar seeks release from detention ordered on 1-10-1973 by the Commissioner of Police, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Ram Bali Rajbhar, in this Habeas Corpus petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India, seeks release from a detention ordered on 1-

facts.text: Grounds of detention supplied to petitioner on 1-10-1973.

anchor.surface_text: 10-1973 by the Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, on the following grounds supplied on the same day to him

facts.text: On 5-9-1973 at about 17-40 hrs., petitioner along with associates Anwar Hossain, Subal Das and others armed with iron rods, lathis and bombs hurled bombs at tea-stall of Lal Mohan Jadav at 19, Coal Berth, Calcutta, because refused to supply tea without payment.

anchor.surface_text: On 5-9-1973 at about 17-40 hrs., you long with your associates Anwar Hossain of 18/2, Mominpur Road, Subal Das of Jhupri at Dock East Boundary Road, Calcutta, and others, all being armed with iron rods, lathis and bombs created a great disturbance of public order by hurling bombs at the tea-stall of Lal Mohan Jadav at 19, Coal Berth, Calcutta, endangering the lives and safety of the stall-owner and other nearby shop-keepers, as he had refused to supply tea to you all, without payment.

facts.text: Incident on 5-9-1973 brought widespread panic, led to closure of shops, suspension of vehicular traffic, jeopardising maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The incident brought widespread panic in the locality, led to the closure of shops, suspension of vehicular traffic, thereby jeopardising the, maintenance of public order.

facts.text: On 7-9-1973 at about 20.05 hrs., petitioner along with associates Kali Das alias Tenia, Subed Ali and others armed with iron-rods, lathis and bombs attacked watch repairing shop of Sk. Azim at 52, Circular Garden Reach Road, Calcutta, by hurling bombs and damaging furniture, watches, show-cases because owner refused to pay for drinks.

anchor.surface_text: On 7-9-1973 at about 20.05 hrs., you along with your associates Kali Das alias Tenia of Jhupri at Strand Road, Calcutta, Subed Ali of 5/2 Bhukailash Road and others, all being armed with iron-rods, lathis and bombs, attacked a Watch Repairing Shop styled as M s. Babloo Watch Repairing Co., at 52, Circular Garden Reach Road, Calcutta, by hurling bombs and damaging furniture, watches, show-cases of the said shop as Sk. Azim, the owner of this shop had earlier refused to pay you all for drinks,

facts.text: During 7-9-1973 incident, when local people intervened, petitioner and associates hurled bombs indiscriminately to kill them, clamping fear in public, affecting public order.

anchor.surface_text: when the local people came to intervene, you all hurled bombs indiscriminately with a view to kill them. The incident clamped fear, frightfulness and insecurity in the minds of the public thereby affecting public order.

facts.text: Petitioner complains that grounds of detention are vague, false, malafide, fanciful, non-existent.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companyplains that the grounds of detention are vague, false, malafide, fanciful, number-existent.

facts.text: Criminal prosecution launched against petitioner on 6-9-1973 for alleged participation in 5-9-1973 incident.

anchor.surface_text: A reference to the facts of the decided cases cited above will indicate that it is number enough that a criminal persecution was launched against the petitioner on 6-9-1973 for the alleged participation of the petitioner in the incident of 5-9-1973.

facts.text: Petitioner discharged by Criminal Court on 1-10-1973.

anchor.surface_text: The Petitioner was discharged by the Criminal Court on 1-10 1973, the very date on which the detention order was made by the Commissioner of Police.

facts.text: Lal Mohan Jadav swore affidavit on 20-11-1973 stating petitioner did not participate in attack on his tea shop on 5-9-1973.

anchor.surface_text: On 20-11-1973, Lal Mohan Jadav swore an affidavit, in the Court of Magistrate 1st Class at Alipore, stating that the petitioner Ram Bali Rajbhar did number participate in the attack on his shop on 5-9-1973 and that he did number mention his name in the First Information Report for that reason.

facts.text: First representation by petitioner against detention received by State Government on 18-10-1973.

anchor.surface_text: On 18-10-1973, a representation by the petitioner against his ,detention was received by the State Government.

facts.text: Detention order approved by State Government on 22-10-1973.

anchor.surface_text: On 22-10-1973, the detention order of the Commissioner of Police was approved by the State Government.

facts.text: Petitioner's case sent to Advisory Board on 23-10-1973 with grounds, representation, and report.

anchor.surface_text: On 23-10-1973, the State, Government sent the petitioners case to the Advisory Board together with the grounds on which the detention was ordered, the representation against it made by the petitioner, and a report made by the Commissioner of Police under Sec. 3, sub. s.  3  of the Act.

facts.text: Advisory Board gave opinion on 5-11-1973 that there was sufficient cause for petitioner's detention.

anchor.surface_text: On 5-11-1973, the Advisory Board, after examining.the case, gave its opinion to the State Government that there was sufficient cause for the petitioners detention.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on 8-11-1973, served on petitioner on 14-11-1973.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companyfirmed the detention order on 8- 11-1973 and- its order was served on the petitioner in jail on 14-11-1973.

facts.text: Petitioner made second representation on 27-11-1973, received by State Government on 28-11-1973.

anchor.surface_text: On 27-11-1973, the petitioner made a second representation which was received by the State Government on 28-11-1973.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court rejected habeas corpus petition under Article 226 on 21-3-1974.

anchor.surface_text: This as still under companysideration when the petitioner filed a Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution to the Calcutta High Court questioning his detention. On 21-3-1973, the Calcutta High Court rejected the Hebeas Corpus petition.

facts.text: Kamal Singh Tiger detained on similar grounds but released by Advisory Board after personal hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner asserts that, on the very grounds on which he was detained, one Kamal Singh Tiger son of Gurmel Singh, who, like the petitioner, was alleged to be homeless in Calcutta, was detained but released after a companysideration of his case by the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Commissioner of Police satisfied from enquiries that petitioner participated in 5-9-1973 incident despite Jadav's affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it is asserted, in the affidavit sworn in by the Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, that the Commissioner was satisfied, from the enquiries made by him through reliable officers, that the petitioner did participate in the alleged incident although he, may have been able to secure an affidavit from Lal Mohan Jadav after his discharge,

facts.text: Division Bench of Calcutta High Court considered effect of Lal Mohan Jadav's affidavit and held it could not vitiate initial detention order.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court had companysidered the effect of the affidavit of Lal Mohan Jadav on the petitioners detention. In our opinion, it had rightly held that the affidavit companyld number vitiate the initial detention order which was passed at a time when numbersuch information companytained in an affidavit was either before the detaining authorities or placed before the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Petitioner's second representation still under consideration at time of Supreme Court petition.

anchor.surface_text: Nevertheless, it does appear to us. from the affidavit of the Commissioner of Police, that the State Govt. had Perhaps number passed any order upon the second representation of the petitioner due to the belief that it may be improper to pass any order on it when, a Habeas Corpus petition of the petitioner is pending.

facts.text: Court directs State Government of West Bengal to consider and decide early on pending second representation of petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above while we reject the petitioners prayer for quashing the detention order, we direct the Government of West Bengal to companysider and take up an early decision upon the pending fresh representation of the petitioner in accordance with the requirements of law and justice as indicated by us above.

holdings.text: There is no misuse of the provisions of Maintenance of Internal Security Act merely because instances of criminal activity are given to arrive at satisfaction for detention for maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: We think it is too late in the day to argue that there is any misuse of the provisions of Maintenance of Internal Security Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  merely because, in order to arrive at a satisfaction that it is necessary to detain a person for the purposes of the security of the State or the maintenance of public order, some instances are given of criminal activity,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preventive detention qualitatively different from punitive; cites precedents Golam Hussain, Haradhan Saha approving use of criminal instances for public order nexus.

holdings.text: An order based on such grounds cannot be said to be affected by extraneous considerations or become mala fide merely because based on criminal instances.

anchor.surface_text: An order based upon such grounds cannot be said to be affected by extraneous considerations or become mala-fide for this reason only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal position clarified in Haradhan Saha; no extraneous or mala fide purpose shown.

holdings.text: Public order is an elastic concept wider than security of the State, separated by disjunctive 'or'; need not be read in conjunction with security of State.

anchor.surface_text: Public Order is necessarily an elastic concept which is, in any case, wider than the security of the State category separated in the Act from it by the disjunctive or.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Section 3(a)(ii); criminal acts can jeopardise public order.

holdings.text: The facts disclose sufficient nexus with public order, not mere cases where ordinary prosecution suffices.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that, in some cases, the facts may so clearly indicate that an ordinary criminal prosecution would suffice that the necessity to order the detention of an offender for one of the objects of the Act could not be said to be reasonably made out. The case before us, however, is not one of those cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application to facts of bomb hurling causing panic, shop closures, traffic suspension.

holdings.text: Interference with subjective satisfaction justified only if no reasonable person could be satisfied on the grounds.

anchor.surface_text: We have to be careful to avoid substituting our own opinion about what is enough for the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authorities with which interference could be justified only if it is clear that no reasonable person could possibly be satisfied about the need to detain on the grounds given

holdings.reasoning_summary: Past conduct furnishes grounds for apprehension; facts reasonable for satisfaction.

holdings.text: All procedural safeguards under MISA complied with, including representation, approval, reference to Advisory Board, confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: On 18-10-1973, a representation by the petitioner against his ,detention was received by the State Government. On 22-10-1973, the detention order of the Commissioner of Police was approved by the State Government... The State Government confirmed the detention order on 8- 11-1973

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sequence of events undisputed; Advisory Board opined sufficient cause.

holdings.text: Petitioner not denied personal hearing or full opportunity before Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner had made no assertion that he did not get a personal hearing by the Advisory Board or that he did not have a full opportunity to make his representations or to put forward his case fully before the Advisory Board

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation by petitioner; Board applied mind differently from Kamal Singh case.

holdings.text: Cases of petitioner and Kamal Singh distinguishable; Board found sufficient cause for petitioner unlike Kamal.

anchor.surface_text: It is evident that Kamal Singh... obtained a personal hearing which satisfied the Advisory Board that his detention was not justified. Apparently, the petitioner could not persuade the Advisory Board, similarly, to believe that his case fell in the same category.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different outcomes after hearing; shows Board applied mind independently.

holdings.text: Lal Mohan Jadav's post-detention affidavit does not vitiate the initial detention order.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court had considered the effect of the affidavit of Lal Mohan Jadav on the petitioners detention. In our opinion, it had rightly held that the affidavit could not vitiate the initial detention order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit after order and Board consideration; Commissioner satisfied via enquiries.

holdings.text: State Government can refer second representation to Advisory Board under Section 14 MISA read with Section 21 General Clauses Act in analogous manner to initial reference.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 1  of the Act lays down 14 1  Without prejudice to the provisions of section 21 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, a detention order may, at any time. be revoked or modified... We think it will be a reasonable, and judicious exercise of the power under Section 14 of the Act to refer a case once again to the Advisory Board

holdings.reasoning_summary: S14 wider power without prejudice to GCA S21; analogous procedure via 'like manner'; implied power for fairness.

holdings.text: No violation of Article 21 or 22; detention prima facie legal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner failed to show infringement; procedure followed; no mala fides.

holdings.text: Prayer for quashing detention order rejected; State directed to expeditiously consider second representation per law.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above while we reject the petitioners prayer for quashing the detention order, we direct the Government of West Bengal to consider and take up an early decision upon the pending fresh representation of the petitioner in accordance with the requirements of law and justice as indicated by us above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All grounds rejected; but natural justice requires prompt consideration of fresh rep.

precedents.case_name: Haradhan Saha v. State of West Bengal & Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: Power of preventive detention is qualitatively different from punitive detention; does not overlap with prosecution even if based on same facts; public order wider than security of State
precedents.cited_holding: The power of preventive detention is qualitatively different from punitive detention. The power of preventive detention is a precautionary power exercised in reasonable anticipation. It may or may not relate to an offence...
